title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
#WOOOOOOOOP
oj <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dominick_oj.csv')
nvars <- format(round(ncol(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",") 
nobs <- format(round(nrow(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",")
The number of variables is 4; the number of observations is 28,947.
Roses are red
violets are blue.

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.1 Data Summary

Summary statistics (Use skimr::skim())

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.2 Data Visualization

oj %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = log(sales), 
             y = log(price),
             color = brand)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .1) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = F) +
  facet_wrap(.~ad) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(legend.position = 'top')

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.3 Data Transformation

ob_sum1 <- oj %>% 
  group_by(brand, ad) %>% 
  summarise(sales_tot = sum(sales, na.rm = T),
            price_mean = round(mean(price, na.rm = T), 2))

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text: 2.4 Analysis

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.5 Quotes

Quote with >


“The truth is rarely pure and never simple.”
— Oscar Wilde

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text:
2.6 Inserting Figures
For a demonstration of a DANL tiger, see Figure 1.





Figure 1: DANL Tiger

title: DANL 200: Introduction to Data AnalyticsProject
text: 2.7 Inserting a HTML page

title: Welcome All!
text:
Welcome to my blog powered by Quarto and GitHub!!

As a Data Analytics major, it is helpful to hone my abilities by doing exploratory data analysis. With that, I will be posting little projects here and there on my website, feel free to take a look!

title: NYC Restaurant Inspections
section: Description of Variables for nyc_rest_ins data frame
text:
Description of Variables for nyc_rest_ins data frame

CAMIS: A unique identifier number for each restaurant
DBA: Stands for “doing business as”, name of the restaurant
BORO: Indentifies the NYC Borough that the restaurant is located in

Manhattan
Bronx
Brooklyn
Queens
Staten Island

STREET: Street address of the restaurant
CUISINE DESCRIPTION: Type of cuisine the restaurant sells
INSPECTION DATE: The date the inspection was performed
ACTION: Indicated the action(s) taken as a result of the inspection
VIOLATION CODE: Violation associated with the restaurant’s inspection
VIOLATION DESCRIPTION: Descriprion of the violation associated with a restaurant’s inspection
CRITICAL FLAG: Indicator of a critical violation as result of inspection

Critical
Not Critical
Not Applicaple

SCORE: Numeric Score for the inspection
Grade: Letter Grade for the Inspection

title: NYC Restaurant Inspections
text:
GRADE and BORO
Graphical representation of the proportion of each GRADE value in each of the 5 values in BORO

nyc1 <- nyc_rest_ins %>% 
  group_by(BORO, GRADE) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n))

ggplot(data = nyc1,
       mapping = aes(x = GRADE, y = prop))+
  geom_bar(aes(fill = GRADE), stat = 'identity')+
  facet_wrap(.~BORO)





Comments on analyses…

All five boroughs seem to have around equal proportions of each Grade

title: NYC Restaurant Inspections
text:
CRITICAL FLAG and BORO
Graphical representation of the count of each value of CRITICAL FLAG per each value of BORO

nyc2 <- nyc_rest_ins %>% 
  group_by(BORO, CRITICAL.FLAG) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n))
View(nyc2)

ggplot(data = nyc2,
       mapping = aes(x = CRITICAL.FLAG, y = n))+
  geom_bar(aes(fill = CRITICAL.FLAG), stat = 'identity')+
  facet_wrap(.~BORO)





Comments on analyses…

The proportion of each value of CRITICAL.FLAG within each of the values of BORO seems to be about equal
This faceted bar chart also gives info about the number of restaurants in each value of BORO within this data set. In order of most to least…

Manhattan has the most restaurants
Brooklyn has the second most
Queens the third most
Bronx second to last
Staten Island is last

title: NYC Restaurant Inspections
text:
GRADE and CRITICAL FLAG
Graphical representation of the proportion of each value of GRADE per value of CRITICAL FLAG

nyc3 <- nyc_rest_ins %>% 
  group_by(GRADE, CRITICAL.FLAG, BORO) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n))
View(nyc3)

ggplot(data = nyc3)+
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = CRITICAL.FLAG, y = prop, fill = GRADE), stat = 'identity', position = 'dodge')





Comments on analyses…

The proportion of each value of GRADE seems to be almost equal per value of CRITICAL FLAG
The proportion of grade A seems to be slightly less for restaurants with No Critical Flags
The proportions of grades B and C appear to be slightly less for restautants with Critical Flags

title: Beer Market Data
section: Description of Variables for beer Data Frame:
text:
Description of Variables for beer Data Frame:

hh: Identification number of the household;
X_purchase_desc: details of item purchased by hh
quantity: number of items purchased by hh
brand: Brand of beer purchased by hh

Bud Light,
Busch Light,
Coors Light,
Miller Lite, or
Natural Light

dollar_spent: Dollar value total of purchase;
beer_floz: volume of beer (fl oz);
price_per_floz: price per fl oz
container: Type of container of beer
promo: Was the item promoted? (coupon, etc…)
market: Scan-track market (or state if rural);
Other demographic data is present in further variables as well…

title: Beer Market Data
text:
Distribution of brand

beer1 <- beer %>% 
  group_by(brand) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n),
         brand_fct = reorder(brand, prop))

ggplot(data = beer1)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = brand_fct, y = prop), stat = 'identity', fill = 'blue')+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+
  labs(title = 'Frequency of Beer Brands',
       x = 'Brand',
       y = 'Proportion')





Comments on analyses…

The brands above are in an increasing order of proportion among the brands in beer data frame

The brands are ordered as follows…

Busch Light
Natural Light
Coors Light
Miller Lite
Bud Light

title: Beer Market Data
text:
brand and dollar spent

beer2 <- beer %>% 
  group_by(brand) %>% 
  summarise(dollar_spent_tot = sum(dollar_spent)) %>% 
  mutate(brand_fct = reorder(brand, dollar_spent_tot)) %>% 
  arrange(-dollar_spent_tot)
View(beer2)

ggplot(beer2)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = brand_fct, y = dollar_spent_tot), stat = 'identity', fill = 'red')+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+
  labs(title = 'Dollars Spent Per Brand',
       x = 'Brand',
       y = 'Dollars Spent')





Comments on analyses….

The order is the same as the distribution of brand within the beer data frame

Just now the y-axis is measuring dollars spent by each value of hh on each brand

Bud Light seems to be most popular all around

title: Beer Market Data
text:
container and brand

beer3 <- beer %>% 
  group_by(brand, container) %>% 
  summarise(n = n())
beer3.5 <- beer3 %>% 
  group_by(brand) %>% 
  slice_max(order_by = n, n = 2)
ggplot(data = beer3.5)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = brand, y = n, fill = container), stat = 'identity', position = 'dodge')+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+
  labs(title = 'Frequency of Cans and Bottles for Each Brand',
       x = 'Brand',
       y = 'Count')



View(beer3.5)


Comments on analyses…

The bar chart above depicts the frequency of two container types (can or non refillable bottle) per each brand

All brands seem to sell more cans than bottles

Of them Bud Light sells the most cans

Bud light also sells the most bottles

title: Possible Data Frames
text: Below are some possible data frames for use in analysis projects.

title: Possible Data Frames
text:
1 Sleep Health Data
Describes trends in sleep health/quality

sleephlth <- read.csv("~/SUNY Geneseo/Classes/Fall 2023/DANL 200 (Team Pr)/dan-noone.github.io/Sleep_health_and_lifestyle_dataset.csv")
nvars <- format(round(ncol(sleephlth), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",") 
nobs <- format(round(nrow(sleephlth), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",")

Number of Variables: 13 Number of Observations: 374

1.1 Description of Variables
- Person ID: Unique identifier for each individual

- Gender: Gender of the person

- Age: The age of the person in years

- Occupation: Occupation of the person

- Sleep Duration: Length of time person sleeps per day (in hours)

- Quality of Sleep: Subjective rating from 1-10 of quality of sleep

- Physical Activity: Length of time person engages in physical activity per day (minutes per day)

- Stress Level: Subjective rating of stress level experienced by person from 1-10

- BMI Category: BMI category of the person
  -Underweight
  -Normal
  -Overweight
  
- Blood Pressure: Blood pressure measurement of the person, systolic over diastolic pressure

- Heart Rate: The resting heart rate of the person in beats per minute

- Daily Steps: The number of steps person takes per day

- Sleep Disorder: The presence or absence of a sleep disorder in the person
  -None
  -Insomnia
  -Sleep Apnea

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text: My repository can be found here

title: HW5 - NFL Data
section: Description of Variables in NFL Data Frame:
text:
Description of Variables in NFL Data Frame:

play_id: Play Id number (numeric), when combined with game_id provides id for single play
game_id: 10 digit id for an NFL game
drive: Drive number (numeric)
week: Season week
posteam: abv for team with possession
qtr: Quarter in the game (qtr 5 means overtime)
half_seconds_remaining: seconds remaining in the half
down: Down for a given play
pass: 1 if a pass play, 0 if not
wp: Estimate for winning probability for posteam given situation at beginning of the play

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2a

In data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs, remove observations for which values of posteam is missing.

Answer:

NFL <- NFL %>% 
  filter(!(is.na(posteam)))

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2b

Summarize the mean value of pass for each posteam when all the following conditions hold:

wp is greater than 20% and less than 75%;
down is less than or equal to 2; and
half_seconds_remaining is greater than 120.


Answer:

NFL_2b <- NFL %>% 
  filter(wp > 0.2 & wp < 0.75 & down <= 2 & half_seconds_remaining > 120)

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2c

Provide both (1) a ggplot code with geom_point() using the resulting data.frame in Q2b and (2) a simple comments to describe the mean value of pass for each posteam.

In the ggplot, reorder the posteam categories based on the mean value of pass in ascending or in descending order.


Answer

NFL_2c <- NFL_2b %>%
  group_by(posteam) %>% 
  mutate(mean_pass = mean(pass)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(posteam_fct = reorder(posteam, mean_pass))

ggplot(data = NFL_2c, mapping = aes(x = mean_pass, y = posteam_fct))+
  geom_point()+
  labs(title = 'Possessing Team and Pass Plays',
       x = 'Percentage of Pass Plays',
       y = 'Team with possession')+
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))+
  theme_minimal()




On the scatter plot there is a positive relationship between posteam and the percentage of pass plays  Teams such as CIN, KC, LAC. and BUF have a higher occurance of pass plays,  While teams such as ATL, WAS, CHI, and NO have a lower occurance of pass plays

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2d

Consider the following data.frame, NFL2022_epa:


NFL2022_epa <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_epa.csv')


Create the data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs_EPA, that includes

All the variables in the data.frame, NFL;
The variables, passer, receiver, and epa, from the data.frame, NFL2022_epa. by joining the two data.frames.

In the resulting data.frame, NFL2022_stuffs_EPA, remove observations with NA in passer.

Answer:

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <- NFL %>% 
  left_join(NFL2022_epa)
View(NFL2022_stuffs_EPA)

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  filter(!(is.na(passer)))

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2e

Provide both (1) a single ggplot and (2) a simple comment to describe the NFL weekly trend of weekly mean value of epa for each of the following two passers,

"J.Allen"
"P.Mahomes"


Answer:

NFL_2e <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  filter(passer == "J.Allen" | passer == "P.Mahomes") %>% 
  group_by(passer, week) %>% 
  summarise(mean_epa = mean(epa))

ggplot(data = NFL_2e,
       mapping = aes(x = week, y = mean_epa, color = passer))+
  geom_line(size = 1, linejoin = 'round')+
  geom_point(size = 1.5)+
  theme(legend.position = 'top')+
  labs(title = "Mean EPA for Two NFL Passers",
       x = 'Week',
       y = 'Mean EPA')+
  scale_color_manual(values = c('blue', 'red'))




P.Mahomes seems to have a higher mean EPA most of the weeks, while J.Allen seems to lag behind

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2f

Calculate the difference between the mean value of epa for "J.Allen" the mean value of epa for "P.Mahomes" for each value of week

Answer:

NFL_2f <- NFL_2e %>% 
  spread(passer, mean_epa) %>% 
  mutate(mean_epa_dif = J.Allen - P.Mahomes)

title: HW5 - NFL Data
text:
Q2g

Summarize the resulting data.frame in Q2d, with the following four variables:

posteam: String abbreviation for the team with possession.
passer: Name of the player who passed a ball to a receiver by initially taking a three-step drop, and backpedaling into the pocket to make a pass. (Mostly, they are quarterbacks.)
mean_epa: Mean value of epa in 2022 for each passer
n_pass: Number of observations for each passer

Then find the top 10 NFL passers in 2022 in terms of the mean value of epa, conditioning that n_pass must be greater than or equal to the third quantile level of n_pass.

Answer:

NFL_2g <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  group_by(posteam, passer) %>% 
  summarise(mean_epa = mean(epa),
            n_pass = n())

Q3_n_pass <- quantile(NFL_2g$n_pass, 0.75)

NFL_2g_2 <- NFL_2g %>% 
  filter(n_pass >= Q3_n_pass) %>% 
  arrange(-mean_epa) %>% 
  head(10)

title: Spotify Listener Data
section: Description of Variables for `spotify Data Frame:
text:
Description of Variables for `spotify Data Frame:

pid: A unique ID for a specific playlist
playlist_name: The name of a specific playlist
pos: Position of the track within a playlist (starting from 0)
artist_name: Name of the artist on the track
track_name: name of the track
duration_ms: duration of the track (in milliseconds)
album_name: name of the track’s album

title: Spotify Listener Data
text:
Top 5 Artists in artist_name

spot1 <- spotify %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  head(5) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n),
         art_fct = reorder(artist_name, prop))
View(spot1)

ggplot(data = spot1)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = art_fct, y = prop, fill = artist_name), stat = 'identity')+
  theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=45,hjust=1,vjust=0.5))+
  ggtitle('Frequency of Top 5 Artists')+
  xlab('Artist Name')+
  ylab('Proportion')



length(unique(spotify$artist_name))

[1] 18866



Comments on analyses…

Out of the 18866 different artist names in the spotify data frame, the top five are…

Drake
Kanye West
Kendrick Lamar
Rihanna
The Weeknd


These are also in order of greatest to least frequency out of the top 5*

title: Spotify Listener Data
text:
Top 5 songs in track_name

spot2 <- spotify %>% 
  group_by(track_name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  head(5) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n/sum(n),
         track_fct = reorder(track_name, prop))

ggplot(data = spot2)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = track_fct, y = prop), stat = 'identity', fill = 'blue')+
  theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=45,hjust=1,vjust=0.5))+
  ggtitle('Top 5 Songs')+
  xlab('Song Name')+
  ylab('Proportion')



length(unique(spotify$track_name))

[1] 64115



Comments on analyses…

There are a total of 64115 unique values in track_name
Out of those 64115 values, the top 5 are…

Closer
One Dance
HUMBLE
Home
Roses


In order of decreasing proportion within the top 5 songs*

title: Spotify Listener Data
section: Most Popular Song in track_name for Each of the Top 5 Artists in artist_name
text:
Most Popular Song in track_name for Each of the Top 5 Artists in artist_name

spot3 <- spotify %>% 
  filter(artist_name %in% spot1$art_fct) %>% 
  group_by(artist_name, track_name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n())
spot3.5 <- spot3 %>% 
  group_by(artist_name) %>% 
  slice_max(order_by = n, n = 1) %>%  #Selects the top n value for each value of artist, the top n rows of top n values
  ungroup() %>% 
  arrange(-n)
  
ggplot(data = spot3.5) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = artist_name, y = n, fill = track_name), stat = 'identity')+
  labs(title = 'Most Popular Song For Each Top 5 Artist',
       x = 'Artist',
       y = 'Count')+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





Comments on analyses…

Above is the top songtrack_name value and it’s count in the spotify data frame for each of the top 5 values of artist_name

Drake : One Dance
Kanye West : GOLD DIGGER
Kendrick Lamar : HUMBLE
Rihanna : Needed Me
The Weeknd : Starboy

title: DANL 200 Project
text:
These data sets were obtained from the EPA website here
These data sets (four in total) measure daily levels of four different gases in different locations

The gases measured are Ozone, SO2 (sulfur dioxide), CO (carbon monoxide), and NO2 (nitrogen dioxide)
These gases play a large role in the measurement of the Air Quality Index (AQI)
They are considered to be atmospheric pollutants
More information on Criteria Air Pollutants can be found here

This project will take a look at and analyze the measurements of these four atmospheric gases per state

These measurements were taken from 01/01/2023 to 09/30/2023





ozone <- read.csv("C:\\Users\\Dan\\OneDrive\\Documents\\SUNY Geneseo\\Classes\\Fall 2023\\DANL 200 (Team Pr)\\dan-noone.github.io\\ozone_measures.csv")
so2 <- read.csv("C:\\Users\\Dan\\OneDrive\\Documents\\SUNY Geneseo\\Classes\\Fall 2023\\DANL 200 (Team Pr)\\dan-noone.github.io\\so2_measures.csv")
co <- read.csv("C:\\Users\\Dan\\OneDrive\\Documents\\SUNY Geneseo\\Classes\\Fall 2023\\DANL 200 (Team Pr)\\dan-noone.github.io\\co_measures.csv")
no2 <- read.csv("C:\\Users\\Dan\\OneDrive\\Documents\\SUNY Geneseo\\Classes\\Fall 2023\\DANL 200 (Team Pr)\\dan-noone.github.io\\no2_measures.csv")


rmarkdown::paged_table(ozone)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(so2)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(co)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(no2)



  







The data sets include a lot of information that is not needed for my analysis

Here I will alter the data sets to include only the information of importance
The data sets will then be row bound using rbind() to create a single data set from the four

For the purpose of continuity, the top 10 most frequent states in ozone data set will also be selected in the other three data sets




st_top10_oz <- ozone %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  head(10) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, n))

ozone_alt <- ozone %>% 
  select(State.Name, Date.Local, Parameter.Name, Units.of.Measure, Arithmetic.Mean) %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_oz$state_fct) %>% 
  rename(Measure = Arithmetic.Mean)
View(ozone_alt)


The new data set ozone_alt includes data for only the 10 most prevalent states in the ozone data set


rmarkdown::paged_table(st_top10_oz)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(ozone_alt)



  







st_top10_so2 <- so2 %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_oz$State.Name) %>%
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, n))

so2_alt <- so2 %>% 
  select(State.Name, Date.Local, Parameter.Name, Units.of.Measure, Arithmetic.Mean) %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_so2$state_fct) %>% 
  rename(Measure = Arithmetic.Mean)


The new data set so2_alt includes data for again, only the 10 most prevalent states in the ozone data set


rmarkdown::paged_table(st_top10_so2)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(so2_alt)



  







st_top10_co <- co %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_oz$State.Name) %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, n))

co_alt <- co %>% 
  select(State.Name, Date.Local, Parameter.Name, Units.of.Measure, Arithmetic.Mean) %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_co$state_fct) %>% 
  rename(Measure = Arithmetic.Mean)


rmarkdown::paged_table(st_top10_co)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(co_alt)



  







st_top10_no2 <- no2 %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_oz$State.Name) %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n()) %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, n))

no2_alt <- no2 %>% 
  select(State.Name, Date.Local, Parameter.Name, Units.of.Measure, Arithmetic.Mean) %>% 
  filter(State.Name %in% st_top10_no2$state_fct) %>% 
  rename(Measure = Arithmetic.Mean)


rmarkdown::paged_table(st_top10_no2)



  


rmarkdown::paged_table(no2_alt)



  








Since the variables are the same, all four data sets can be row bound together using rbind()


air_qual <- rbind(ozone_alt, so2_alt, co_alt, no2_alt)
rmarkdown::paged_table(air_qual)

title: DANL 200 Project
text:
Since the variables are the same, all four data sets can be row bound together using rbind()


air_qual <- rbind(ozone_alt, so2_alt, co_alt, no2_alt)
rmarkdown::paged_table(air_qual)

title: DANL 200 Project
text:
2.1 Description of the Variables

State.Name: A character variable whose values are one of the 10 states most frequent in the ozone data set

Arizona
California
Colorado
Florida
Illinois
Indiana
Ohio
Pennsylvania
Texas
Utah

Date.Local: The date the measurement of the atmospheric gas was taken
Parameter.Name: The atmospheric gas being measured
Units.of.Measure: Units in which the atmospheric gas was measured

Parts Per Million : Ozone, Carbon Monoxide
Parts Per Billion : Sulfur Dioxide, Nitrogen Dioxide

Measure: The mean measurement of the gas in the units provided in Units.of.Measure

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 2.2 Distribution of each value of State.Name per value of Parameter.Name
text:
2.2 Distribution of each value of State.Name per value of Parameter.Name

The distribution of each state in the ten provided, per each atmospheric gas being measured


air_qual_state_dist <- air_qual %>% 
  group_by(State.Name, Parameter.Name) %>% 
  summarise(n = n())
View(air_qual_state_dist)

ggplot(data = air_qual_state_dist)+
  geom_bar(aes(y = State.Name, x = n, fill = State.Name), stat = 'identity')+
  facet_wrap(.~Parameter.Name)+
  theme_gray()+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1))+
  labs(title = 'State Distribution per Gas',
       x = 'Count',
       y = 'State')




Analyses

Depicted in the above figure is a faceted bar chart depicting the count of each state in which each atmospheric gas was measured

It seems as though carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and ozone were measured most often in California
Sulfur dioxide (SO2) was measured most frequently in Ohio and secondly in Texas

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 2.3 The average measurement of the OZONE measurement per each State.Name value
text:
2.3 The average measurement of the OZONE measurement per each State.Name value

The average measurement of ozone in parts per million (ppm) per each state in the top ten most frequent


ozone_alt_per_state <- ozone_alt %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(mean_ppm = mean(Measure)) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, mean_ppm))

ggplot(data = ozone_alt_per_state)+
  geom_bar(aes(y = state_fct, x = mean_ppm, fill = state_fct), stat = 'identity')+
  theme_dark()+
  labs(title = 'Ozone Levels in ppm per State',
       x = ' Mean ppm Value',
       y = 'State',
       fill = 'State')+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno')




Analyses

In the bar chart shown above depicts a decent variation in Ozone levels between the 10 states

Texas, Florida, and California seem to have the lowest levels of Ozone

Colorado, Utah, and Arizona seem to have the highest levels of Ozone

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 2.4 The average measurement of the SULFUR DIOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value
text:
2.4 The average measurement of the SULFUR DIOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value

The average measurment of sulfur dioxide (SO2) in parts per billion (ppb) per each state in the top ten most frequent


so2_alt_per_state <- so2_alt %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(mean_ppb = mean(Measure)) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, mean_ppb))

ggplot(data = so2_alt_per_state)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = mean_ppb, y = state_fct, fill = state_fct), stat = 'identity')+
  theme_dark()+
  labs(title = 'Sulfur Dioxide Levels in ppb per State',
       x = 'Mean ppb Value',
       y = 'State',
       fill = 'State')+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno')




Analyses

There seems to be even greater variation between each of the state’s Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) levels

California, Arizona, and Ohio seem to have the lowest levels of SO2

Colorado, Texas, and Utah seem to have the highest levels of SO2

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 2.5 The average measurement of the CARBON MONOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value
text:
2.5 The average measurement of the CARBON MONOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value

The average measurment of carbon monoxide (CO) in parts per million (ppm) per each state in the top ten most frequent


co_alt_per_state <- co_alt %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(mean_ppm = mean(Measure)) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, mean_ppm))

ggplot(data = co_alt_per_state)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = mean_ppm, y = state_fct, fill = state_fct), stat = 'identity')+
  theme_dark()+
  labs(title = 'Carbon Monoxide Levels in ppm per State',
       x = 'Mean ppm Value',
       y = 'State',
       fill = 'State')+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno')




Analyses

In the bar chart, there seems to be less variation in Carbon Monoxide (CO) levels as compared to Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)

Utah, Ohio, and Illinois seem to have the lowest levels of CO

Indiana, Florida, and Pennsylvania seem to have the highest levels of CO

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 2.6 The average measurement of the NITROGEN DIOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value
text:
2.6 The average measurement of the NITROGEN DIOXIDE measurment per each State.Name value

The average measurement of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) in parts per billion (ppb) per each state in the top ten most frequent


no2_alt_per_state <- no2_alt %>% 
  group_by(State.Name) %>% 
  summarise(mean_ppb = mean(Measure)) %>% 
  mutate(state_fct = reorder(State.Name, mean_ppb))

ggplot(data = no2_alt_per_state)+
  geom_bar(aes(x = mean_ppb, y = state_fct, fill = state_fct), stat = 'identity')+
  theme_dark()+
  labs(title = 'Nitrogen Dioxide Levels in ppb per State',
       x = 'Mean ppb Value',
       y = ' State',
       fill = 'State')+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno')




Analyses

The variation of Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) seems to be similar to that of Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)

Indiana, Texas, and Utah seem to have the lowest levels of NO2

Arizona, Illinois, and Colorado seem to have the highest levels of NO2

title: DANL 200 Project
section: 3.1 What do these levels even mean?
text:
3.1 What do these levels even mean?

These four gases (Ozone, SO2, CO, and NO2) are considered to be Criteria Air Pollutants by the EPA

Being Criteria Air Pollutants (along with Lead (Pb), and Particulate Matter (PM)), they pose adverse health and environmental effects.




3.1.1 Ozone

Ground-level ozone (as measured in the data), comes from reaction between pollutants

These pollutants are emitted by industrial facilities, electric utilities, and motor vehicles

This Ground-level ozone (in contrast with ozone that protects from UV rays), can pose health risks

These health risks include…

Inflammation of lining of the lungs
Reduced lung function
Cough, wheezing, chest pain, shortness of breath
Increased susceptibility to respiratory infection, and
Premature mortality, to name a few.



Analyses Pertaining to the Data:

For the states such as Colorado, Utah, and Arizona some of these health effects could potentially be more frequent

However, in states such as Texas, Florida, and California these health effects will most likely not be as prevalent




3.1.2 Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)

This air pollutant comes primarily from fossil fuel combustion by industrial and electrical facilities
Short-term exposure by asthmatic individuals may result in…

Wheezing
Chest Tightness
Shortness of Breath
Etc…

Mostly affects the respiratory system

Analyses Pertaining to the Data:

Colorado would most likely experience the highest frequency of these health effects as the average measure of SO2 over the time frame is almost double that of Texas (the state with the second highest measurement)

California is the state with the lowest average level of SO2, and would most likely see the least health effects




3.1.3 Carbon Monoxide (CO)

The primary source of Carbon Monoxide is found to be fuel propelled means of transportation
Primary health risks as a result of exposure are…

Decreased capacity of blood to carry oxygen

Which can cause myocardial ischemia (reduced oxygen to heart)
and angina (chest pain)



Analyses Pertaining to the Data:

States such as Indiana, Florida, and Pennsylvania which had the highest average levels of CO, would most likely see the highest frequency of health effects

Utah, which had the lowest average level of CO (almost half the average level of Indiana), would most likely experience the lowest frequency of health effects




3.1.4 Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2)

Primarily emitted from cars, trucks, buses, power plants, and other engines/equipment

Nitrogen Oxide (NO) is emitted first and then rapidly oxidized into NO2 in the atmosphere

Health risks include mostly respiratory related symptoms and hospital visits

Analyses Pertaining to the Data:

States such as Arizona and Illinois had the highest average level of NO2 recorded, so they would most likely experience the highest frequency of these health effects

States such as Utah and Texas had an average recorded level of NO2 about half that of Arizona and Illinois, and would most likely experience the lowest frequency of health effects

title: Using Python and R Together
text:
In Python, variables can store data of different types without explicitly declaring the type.
For example:

integer_variable = 10
string_variable = 'Hello'
float_variable = 10.5

float_variable

10.5





Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

# Equals: a == b
# Not Equals: a != b
# Less than: a < b
# Less than or equal to: a <= b
# Greater than: a > b
# Greater than or equal to: a >= b

These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in ‘if statements’ and loops.

# if statement:
if 5 > 2:
    print('Five is greater than two!')

Five is greater than two!





A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.
A function can return data as a result.

# Defining a function:
def my_function():
    print('Hello from a function')

# Calling a function:
my_function()

Hello from a function





A list is a collection which is ordered and changeable.
A dictionary is a collection which is unordered, changeable and indexed.

# List example:
my_list = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']

# Dictionary example:
my_dict = {'name': 'John', 'age': 36}

title: Using Python and R Together
text:
2.2 Python-R Interaction
Below is using Python’s DataFrame oj to visualize using R’s ggplot

library(tidyverse)

# Access the Python pandas DataFrame
oj <- py$oj

# Plot using ggplot2
ggplot(oj, aes(x = log(sales), y = log(price), 
               color = brand)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .25) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm) +
  theme_minimal()





2.2.1 Interactive DataFrame with R’s DT Package







In *.ipynb on Google Colab, we can use itables or just Google Colab’s default to print DataFrame.

# !pip install itables
from itables import init_notebook_mode, show
init_notebook_mode(all_interactive=False)

oj = pd.read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dominick_oj.csv')
show(oj)

Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

# Equals: a == b

# Less than or equal to: a <= b
# Greater than: a > b

A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.

title: Daniel Noone
text:
---
title: 'Python Basics'
author: 'Daniel Noone'
date: '02-10-2024'
categories: [Python]
---

SyntaxError: invalid syntax (<ipython-input-1-4b089545c646>, line 1)

title: Python Basics
text:
1 Introduction
This blog post is meant to give a brief introduction of some of the main topics in basic python programming


2 Variables & Assignment

In python programming, variables are just names for values not actual storage places. 
These values can be singular such as a numeric value of 10, but there can also be multiple values of the same or varying data types 
an equal sign = is used to assign values to their respective variables (or objects)


# Single value
x = 10

# Multiple values
y = [1,2,3]

#Multiple types
z = ['a','b','c',1,2,3]



3 Data Types in Python
There are multiple different data types recognized by the python language.
The most basic types are as follows:

# Integer, numeric values with no decimals
x = 10

# Float, numeric values with decimals
y = 10.99

# String, character values surrounded by '' or ""
z = 'hello, world' #OR 
z = "hello, world"

# Boolean, logical values
x = True
y = False

# Nothing, no value
z = None

# List, data container for any data type (even multiple types at once)
list_ = [10, 1.55, 'apple', True, False, None]

# Tuple, non mutable data container
tup = (2, 3 , 4)

# Set
set_ = {'a', 'b'}

# Dictionary
dict_ = {'first': 'a', 'second': 'b'}



4 Operators
Mathematical operations can also be done in python using preset operators:

# Addition
x = 5 + 5 # x would have value of 10
y = x + 5 # y would have value of 15

# Subtraction
x = 5 - 1 # x would have value of 4
y = x - 2 # y would have value of 2

# Multiplication and Exponents (* for multiplication, ** for exponents)
x = 5 * 2**2 # x would have value of 20
y = x**2 * 5 # y would have value of 2000

# Division and Integer Division (if want int type out of operation, use //)
x = 4/2 # x would have value of 2.0
y = x/2 # y would have value of 1.0

x = 8//2 # x would have value of 4 (int type not float)
y = x//2 # y would have value of 2 (again, int not float)

# Can also perform string concatenation
str_one = 'hello,'
str_two = ' world'
str_ = str_one + str_two # Result of summation is concatenation of str_one and str_two 
                          # = 'hello, world'



5 Conditionals
Can perform conditional operations in python

If statements
If else
etc…


# Can use if and elif and else to formulate conditional operations
# For example...

name = 'David'
score = 99

if name == 'David' and score >= 90:
  print('Great job, David!')
elif name != 'David' and score >= 90:
  print('Great job, stranger!')
elif name == 'David' and score < 90:
  print('You failed, David!')
elif name != 'David' and score < 90:
  print('You failed, stranger!')

-> Here the result is 'Great job, David!' since the name is 'David' and the score is 99


6 Casting Variables
Casting is when we explicitly assign a data type to a variable

str() will convert to string type
int() will convert to integer type
float() will convert to float type


x = 10 # integer type
y = '20' # string type
z = 1.55 # float type

x_ = float(x) # makes 10 into float type = 10.0
y_ = int(y) # makes '20' into int type = 20
z_ = int(z) # makes 1.55 into int type = 1 (DOES NOT ROUND)
x_str = str(x) # makes 10 into str type = '10'



7 Slicing Methods

Python uses indexing to slice data
The index starts at 0, not 1



As seen in the image, negative values can also be used
The syntax is as follows

[:] - will return the whole value
[start :] - will return from a starting index value until the end
[: end] - will return from the start until the end index value
[start : end] - Will return from start value to end value
[start : end: step] - will return from start to end by a certain step amount



string = 'abcdefghij'

string[:5] # returns 'abcde' (first 5 characters of string)
string[5:] # returns 'fghij' (last 5 characters of string)
string[0:5:2] # returns 'ace' (first 5 characters, but in steps of 2)

list_ = ['apple','banana','pear','strawberry','papaya','pineapple']

list_[:3] # returns ['apple', 'banana', 'pear'] (first 3 elements of list)
list_[3:] # returns ['strawberry', 'papaya', 'pineapple'] (last 3 elements of list)
list_[0::2] # returns ['apple', 'pear', 'papaya'] (whole list by steps of 2)



8 Importing Modules, Packages and Libraries

Module - a bunch of related code saved in a file with extension .py
Package - directory of a collection of modules
Library - a collection of packages
import is called on a module to be able to use it

Then have to call module along with any functions associated



import pandas
# could then use pandas.read_csv() to read a csv


import as is called on a module to give it a name to make things more efficient


import pandas as pd
# Then could use pd.read_csv() instead of pandas.read_csv()


from and import is used to load a specific function from a module


from pandas import read_csv
# then can just use read_csv() as if it were a base function


In order to install a module, package or library - have to call pip install in terminal or !pip install if on Google Colab

!pip install is also used for Rstudio



# !pip install itables
